entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin separalis, from Latin separ separate, back-formation from separare to separate

def.dt: :separate or distinct from one another federal union of the several states
:individually owned or controlled :exclusive a several fishery compare common
:of or relating separately to each individual involved a several judgment
:being separate and distinctive :respective specialists in their several fields
:more than two but fewer than many moved several inches
:an indefinite number more than two and fewer than many several of the guests
